Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the rate of fraud in the Earned Income Tax Credit, Medicare, Medicaid, and food stamps programs.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the stated rate of fraud.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the rate of fraud is the same across all four programs, which may not be accurate.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation that the claim may have been referring to error rates instead of actual fraud rates.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not accurately distinguishing between fraud and error rates.
Understate: The claim may be understating the actual rate of fraud in the programs, as the expert indicates that the error rates include instances of fraud.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence to support the 20 to 25 percent rate of fraud in the programs.
